author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: ‘From the Front Lines,’ Stories of Resistance and a Movement for Black Lives
description: In an interview, Saidu Tejan-Thomas Jr., the creator of the podcast, Resistance, talked about the movement unfolding in Nigeria, with regular demonstrations against police brutality.
content: The hashtag #EndSARS first surfaced in 2017 as activists in Nigeria sought to abolish a federal police unit called the Special Anti-Robbery Squad that residents said had misused its power. Known as SARS, demonstrators accused the unit of inflicting violence on residents.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Sam Ezersky helps us work off the turkey with an invigorating variety puzzle.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Sam Ezersky manages to get two 15-letter puns into a very substantial puzzle this week, as well as some very jubilant smaller entries and a couple of stumpers. I’m leaving out the anagrams this time and linking to spoilers, and if you are new to “Panda” puzzles, use this excellent little glossary as you solve with us. This being a Panda, expect some variation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Sometimes, It’s OK to Bark in Meetings
description: Some of our favorite new colleagues are four-legged and furry.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Assassination in Iran Could Limit Biden’s Options. Was That the Goal?
description: The killing of Iran’s top nuclear scientist is likely to impede the country’s military ambitions. Its real purpose may have been to prevent the president-elect from resuming diplomacy with Tehran.
content: WASHINGTON — The assassination of the scientist who led Iran’s pursuit of a nuclear weapon for the past two decades threatens to cripple President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s effort to revive the Iran nuclear deal before he can even begin his diplomacy with Tehran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Hank Stephenson
title: Arizona Settles In to Life as a ‘Magenta’ State
description: Democrats made historic inroads. But it’s a deeply divided place, and some say a “blood bath” is on the horizon in 2022.
content: PHOENIX — In the moonlight, dozens of people hollered and embraced, dropping the rules of social distancing as they celebrated a win after a long year: hundreds of thousands of Latino voters registered, calls made and doors knocked amid a pandemic that had devastated their communities. Though it would be days before the final result in Arizona was clear, the people working to shore up Latino support for Democrats in the state were already convinced that they helped shape history. They had come through the crucible of a pervasive anti-immigrant sentiment and a decade later, flipped the state and delivered wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geraldine Fabrikant
title: The World’s Most Glamorous Quarantine Project
description: While you’ve been binge-watching Netflix and peering anxiously at your sourdough, John Hatleberg has been working on replicas of the Hope Diamond and its earlier incarnations for the Smithsonian.
content: In the midst of the pandemic, diamonds (at least newly mined ones) may have lost their luster. But in the studio of his New York apartment, John Hatleberg is betting it will soon be back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A video in a hospital courtyard captures an 81-year-old Italian’s serenade to his dying wife.
description: Because of coronavirus restrictions in Italy, thousands of people have not been able to visit loved ones in hospitals, regardless of their ailment.
content: Because of coronavirus restrictions in Italy, thousands of people have not been able to visit loved ones in hospitals, regardless of their ailment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: A.A. to Zoom, Substance Abuse Treatment Goes Online
description: It began as a stopgap way to get through the pandemic, but both participants and providers say virtual sessions have some clear advantages and will likely become a permanent part of recovery.
content: Until the coronavirus pandemic, their meetings took place quietly, every day, discreet gatherings in the basements of churches, a spare room at the YMCA, the back of a cafe. But members of Alcoholics Anonymous and other groups of recovering substance abusers found the doors quickly shut this spring, to prevent the spread of Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Macron Says Images of French Police Beating Black Man ‘Shame Us’
description: President Emmanuel Macron called for reaffirming “the link of confidence that should naturally exist between the French and those who protect them.”
content: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France said on Friday that video images showing police officers beating a Black man “shame us,” and he condemned violence both by and against the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Protests Over Security Bill in France Draw Tens of Thousands
description: Demonstrators accused the government of drifting toward repressive policies with a measure that would restrict the sharing images of police officers and strengthen government surveillance tools.
content: PARIS — Tens of thousands of people took to the streets across France on Saturday to protest a security bill that would restrict sharing images of police officers and strengthen government surveillance tools, the latest sign that anger over recent cases of police violence is galvanizing opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Guns, Drugs and Viral Content: Welcome to Cartel TikTok
description: Mexico is set to shatter another murder record, but that grim reality is nowhere to be seen on the TikTok videos that go viral by showcasing drug cartel culture.
content: MEXICO CITY — Tiger cubs and semiautomatic weapons. Piles of cash and armored cars. Fields of poppies watered to the sound of ballads glorifying Mexican drug cartel culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Rifkin
title: Tony Hsieh, Longtime Chief of Zappos, Is Dead at 46
description: In the early days of online retailing, he realized that the key to success was making people feel comfortable and secure shopping on the internet.
content: Tony Hsieh, the technology entrepreneur and venture capitalist who built Zappos into a $1 billion internet shoes and clothing powerhouse, died on Friday.  He was 46.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Kathleen Gray
title: In Key States, Republicans Were Critical in Resisting Trump’s Election Narrative
description: They refuted conspiracy theories, certified results, dismissed lawsuits and repudiated a president of their own party.
content: The telephone call would have been laugh-out-loud ridiculous if it had not been so serious. When Tina Barton picked up, she found someone from President Trump’s campaign asking her to sign a letter raising doubts about the results of the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Joseph Goldstein and Mitch Smith
title: Virus Deaths Approach Spring Record Amid Changing U.S. Crisis
description: On April 15, more Americans were reported dead of Covid-19 than on any other day of the pandemic. The daily toll is growing close once more.
content: On April 15, the United States reached a grim nadir in the pandemic: 2,752 people across the country were reported to have died from Covid-19 that Wednesday, more than on any day before or since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: As Hiking Surges During the Pandemic, So Do Injuries
description: Novice hikers and climbers have flocked to the outdoors, but some are unprepared for the dangers on the trails.
content: Outdoor activities have become a popular pastime during the coronavirus pandemic as adventure seekers and couch surfers alike take to hiking trails for a bit of a reprieve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Biden Aides’ Ties to Consulting and Investment Firms Pose Ethics Test
description: Some of the president-elect’s choices for top posts have done work for undisclosed corporate clients and aided a fund that invests in government contractors.
content: WASHINGTON — One firm helps companies navigate global risks and the political and procedural ins and outs of Washington. The other is an investment fund with a particular interest in military contractors.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 47 Recipes for Thanksgiving Leftovers
description: They’re quite possibly the best part of the holiday.
content: Did you go too big with your turkey? Have stuffing for days? Don’t worry, we have lots of suggestions for what to do with it all. You could make Sohla El-Waylly’s Thanksgiving leftovers sandwich (above) or her stuffing dumpling soup, or Samin Nosrat’s turkey tikka masala. Kids and adults alike will love Margaux Laskey’s leftovers enchilada pie. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Ronen Bergman and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Brazen Killings Expose Iran’s Vulnerabilities as It Struggles to Respond
description: After suffering a string of audacious attacks, Tehran faces an agonizing choice: embracing hard-liner demands for swift retaliation, or trying to make a fresh start with the Biden administration.
content: The raid alone was brazen enough. A team of Israeli commandos with high-powered torches blasted their way into a vault of a heavily guarded warehouse deep in Iran and made off before dawn with 5,000 pages of top secret papers on the country’s nuclear program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and John Ismay
title: Los Angeles Bans Almost All Public Gatherings to Stop Virus Surge
description: Los Angeles County is now seeing almost 5,000 new virus cases a day. The order, which even restricts functions in private homes, takes effect Monday.
content: SACRAMENTO — The Los Angeles County Department of Public Health on Friday called on residents to stay home as the virus continues its rapid surge, barring gatherings both in public at private homes if people are from different households.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa and Sarah Cahalan
title: U.S. coronavirus cases pass 4 million for the month of November, doubling the record set in October.
description: The total number of coronavirus cases in the United States for November surpassed four million on Saturday, more than double the record set in October of 1.9 million cases. And the sharp escalation is likely to continue — or grow even steeper.
content: The total number of coronavirus cases in the United States for November surpassed four million on Saturday, more than double the record set in October of 1.9 million cases. And the sharp escalation is likely to continue — or grow even steeper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: How Democrats Suffered Crushing Down-Ballot Losses Across America
description: In statehouse races, suburban voters’ disgust with President Trump failed to translate into a rebuke of other Republicans, ensuring the party’s grip on partisan mapmaking.
content: WEXFORD, Pa. — Just a few seats shy of a majority in the State House of Representatives, Democrats in Pennsylvania this year zeroed in on Republican-held suburban districts, where disdain for President Trump ran hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Plastic Dividers and Masks All Day: What Teaching in a Pandemic Looks Like
description: As school districts diverge on handling the pandemic, Baltimore City Public Schools are slowly trying to get students back in the classroom. It has not been easy, but neither has remote learning.
content: BALTIMORE — Zia Hellman prepared to welcome her kindergarten students back to Walter P. Carter Elementary/Middle School this month the way any teacher would on the first day of school: She fussed over her classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Murphy
title: Pandemic-Proof Your Habits
description: Too many people are still longing for their old routines. Get some new ones instead.
content: I attended a Thanksgiving dinner several years ago where the hostess, without warning family and friends, broke with tradition and served salmon instead of turkey, roasted potatoes instead of mashed, raspberry coulis instead of cranberry sauce and … you get the idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell and Oskar Garcia
title: What to Watch When Mike Tyson Fights Roy Jones Jr.
description: Is this for real? Yes. Sort of. Just expect more spectacle than high-level boxing.
content: Mike Tyson will box Roy Jones Jr. on Saturday night. (No, we haven’t entered some kind of time warp.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times and The Associated Press
title: Ohio State cancels a game after a coronavirus outbreak, potentially imperiling its Big Ten chances.
description: Ohio State has called off its football game scheduled for Saturday at Illinois after coronavirus testing revealed an increasing number of cases on the team. The cancellation was announced hours after the university revealed that Ryan Day, the head coach of the fourth-ranked Buckeyes, had tested positive and would not travel to the game.
content: Ohio State has called off its football game scheduled for Saturday at Illinois after coronavirus testing revealed an increasing number of cases on the team. The cancellation was announced hours after the university revealed that Ryan Day, the head coach of the fourth-ranked Buckeyes, had tested positive and would not travel to the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Kwak-Hefferan
title: There’s No Better Time to Clear the Air
description: It’s discomforting to realize that air pollution can be coming from inside your home. Here’s how to identify and rid yourself of the risks.
content: Think about the phrase “air pollution.” Are you picturing black plumes curling out of factory smokestacks and the tailpipes of idling vehicles? Something to worry about outdoors, that is, not inside your home? Not so fast: Air pollutants could be within your own walls too, seeping from your furnace, your basement, even that new couch, and their threats range from eye irritation to an increased risk of cancer, and maybe even death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Neighbor’s Dogs Are Driving Me Crazy. What Can I Do?
description: Incessant barking is the top complaint to animal-control centers. As always, it’s better to start with a personal approach.
content: Q: I live in a quiet suburban neighborhood in Metuchen, N.J. Neighbors whose backyard abuts ours have two very large dogs that they leave outside all day, and the dogs bark incessantly and loudly. Six months into this pandemic, my other neighbors and I are stretched to the limit, as we are working from home and the noise diminishes our quality of life. What recourse do we have?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Adriana Zehbrauskas
title: A Rush to Expand the Border Wall That Many Fear Is Here to Stay
description: Despite the president-elect’s vow to halt the project, the Trump administration is expanding the wall at a breakneck pace.
content: DOUGLAS, Ariz. — Four years ago, President Trump took office with a pledge to build a towering wall on America’s border with Mexico — a symbol of his determination to halt immigration from countries to the south and build a barrier that would long outlast him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Closing Time for a Village’s Last Pub?
description: With a deadline looming, locals scramble to raise enough money to buy the White Horse Tavern — and save the soul of their community.
content: STONESFIELD, England — Seven pubs in this tiny village in West Oxfordshire have closed over the years, and some residents here still talk about each as if it were a beloved relative who had expired last week. The Black Head? Turned into a private home. Rose & Crown? Demolished and replaced with a row of houses. The Boot Inn? Kaput.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: For the World Economy, a Grim Slog Tempered by New Hopes
description: The emergence of vaccines has taken the edge off the worst fears, but a meaningful economic recovery probably remains distant.
content: Nearly a year into a pandemic that has ravaged the global economy like no time since the Great Depression, the only clear pathway toward improved fortunes is containing the virus itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelsey Osgood
title: What We Can Learn From Solitude
description: Contemporary hermits are reaching out to people struggling with isolation. Their message: Go inward, and get outside.
content: Since the beginning of the pandemic, Paul Fredette and Karen Karper Fredette have made some changes to their lives: Ms. Fredette stopped attending her local exercise class, and the couple whittled their interactions with their neighbors down to waves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Scathing Ruling Sinks President in Pennsylvania
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 28, 2020.
content: “Voters, not lawyers, choose the president. Ballots, not briefs, decide elections.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Pedophile Scandal Can’t Crack the Closed Circles of Literary France
description: The scandal surrounding the writer Gabriel Matzneff was not limited to his pedophilia. It also opened a window on the entrenched and clubby nature of many of France’s elite institutions.
content: PARIS — One of France’s most prestigious literary awards, the Renaudot can change a writer’s career overnight. Prizewinners jump onto best-seller lists. Publishers earn bragging rights in a nation that places literature at the heart of its sense of grandeur and global standing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Six-Pack
description: Eric Berlin puts the squeeze on with a muscular Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you’re into solving unusual variety puzzles, you’re hopefully familiar with Eric Berlin — he’s behind two new creations in The New York Times this year as well as Puzzlesnacks, an ongoing series of inventive puzzles for children and adults. I was surprised to find that it had been a couple of years since we’ve had a Sunday puzzle from Mr. Berlin. (His most recent was the “Escape Room” contest puzzle from 2018 — I have to remember to ask if there’s a contest this year.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: As Iran Threatens Payback After Assassination, Germany Urges Restraint
description: The killing of Iran’s top nuclear scientist, which Tehran blamed on Israel, raised fears of an escalation in violent retribution.
content: Iran’s leaders threatened on Saturday to retaliate over the assassination of the country’s top nuclear scientist, blaming Israel and pledging to continue the work of the man who American and Israeli officials believe was the architect of what they call the country’s secretive nuclear weapons program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Joseph Goldstein and Mitch Smith
title: Daily Covid-19 deaths in the U.S. rise back toward the record level set in April.
description: On April 15, 2,752 people across the United States were reported to have died from Covid-19, more than on any day before or since.
content: On April 15, 2,752 people across the United States were reported to have died from Covid-19, more than on any day before or since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Ohio State Cancels Football Game Against Illinois Amid Virus Outbreak
description: The university announced the cancellation hours after reporting that the coach of the fourth-ranked Buckeyes, Ryan Day, had tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: Ohio State on Friday night called off its football game scheduled for Saturday at Illinois after coronavirus testing revealed an increasing number of cases on the team. The cancellation was announced hours after the university revealed that Ryan Day, the head coach of the fourth-ranked Buckeyes, had tested positive and would not travel to the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Let’s Talk About Higher Wages
description: The nation, and the Democratic Party, desperately needs a replacement for the tired story that tax cuts drive economic growth.
content: One of the great successes of the Republican Party in recent decades is the relentless propagation of a simple formula for economic growth: tax cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Pick to Head Holocaust Memorial Stirs International Uproar
description: Critics are protesting the nomination of Effie Eitam, a retired general and far-right politician, to lead Yad Vashem, a hallowed Israeli institution.
content: JERUSALEM — For years, his name was synonymous with intolerance and right-wing extremism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: 19th-Century Ship Is Revealed by Storm Erosion in Florida
description: Researchers believe the vessel is the Caroline Eddy, a ship built during the Civil War and wrecked in 1880. “It was a sea like a mountain,” its captain recounted at the time.
content: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — Not long after the Caroline Eddy set sail in 1880 from Florida with cargo bound for up the coast, a powerful hurricane nearly tore it apart, casting the crew, clinging to the rigging, adrift for two days before the wreck washed ashore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
title: Gunmen Assassinate Iran’s Top Nuclear Scientist in Ambush, Provoking New Crisis
description: Iran expressed fury over the killing of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, blaming it on Israel and the United States. His death may complicate President-elect Biden’s intention to restore the Iranian nuclear deal.
content: Iran’s top nuclear scientist, long identified by American and Israeli intelligence as the guiding figure behind a covert effort to design an atomic warhead, was shot and killed Friday in what the Iranian media called a roadside ambush as he and his bodyguards traveled outside Tehran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Marks
title: Ethiopia Claims Victory in Tigray Conflict After Shelling Restive Region’s Capital
description: After heavy artillery strikes on Saturday, the federal government claimed the city of Mekelle was now under its control, but there was no way to independently confirm the assertion.
content: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Ethiopia claimed victory in its conflict with the restive region of Tigray on Saturday, after a daylong series of artillery strikes against the regional capital, a city of half a million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Says Too Much
description: Nam Jin Yoon’s Saturday puzzle rolls off the tongue.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — A week ago, we got a taste of hyperdifficulty. This puzzle, Nam Jin Yoon’s second construction for us and his Saturday debut, is like a soft cozy sweater compared with Sam Ezersky’s, um, horsehair shirt (or whatever itchy garment you can imagine). There are loads of great culture references, mingling with gently funny puns and hardly any noticeable glue. There are even a couple of prompts for what to read and watch, assuming you’re still holidaying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Sarah Fuller, With a Kickoff, Is the First Woman to Play Football in a Power 5 Game
description: Fuller, a goalkeeper for Vanderbilt’s women’s soccer team, was asked to play because the football team’s kicking unit could not practice because of the coronavirus.
content: Sarah Fuller became the first woman to play during a regular-season game in one of college football’s Power 5 conferences by booting a kickoff on Saturday for Vanderbilt to start the second half against Missouri.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: Beijing Takes Its South China Sea Strategy to the Himalayas
description: China built a village in territory also claimed by the kingdom of Bhutan, echoing its aggressive tactics at the border with India and in places much farther away.
content: Just in time for its National Day in October, China completed construction of a new village high in the mountains where the Chinese region of Tibet meets the kingdom of Bhutan. A hundred people moved into two dozen new homes beside the Torsa River and celebrated the holiday by raising China’s flag and singing the national anthem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Payne and Katherine Cusumano
title: How to Build a Guitar
description: For The New York Times for Kids, the photographer Christopher Payne visited the Martin Guitars factory to see how humans and machines make music.
content: When a guitarist plucks a guitar string, it starts to quiver back and forth — setting off a cascade of vibrations along the length of the instrument. The vibrations travel down the strings to the top of the guitar, called the soundboard, and then displace the air inside the body. The air bounces off the stiff wooden back and sides and bursts out of the sound hole: a musical note.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Jonathan Martin
title: Top Contenders for Biden’s Cabinet Draw Fire From All Sides
description: Lists of names of those the president-elect is said to be considering are flying across Washington, prompting lawmakers and interest groups to raise questions about some top contenders.
content: WASHINGTON — There are leading candidates and dark horses. There are potential roadblocks from progressives and conservatives. And there are competing factions hoping to be part of the next president’s inner circle, all jockeying for influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood’s Obituary, the Sequel. Now Streaming.
description: In the 110-year history of the American film industry, never has so much upheaval arrived so quickly and on so many fronts.
content: LOS ANGELES — “Hollywood’s like Egypt: full of crumbled pyramids. It’ll never come back. It’ll just keep on crumbling until finally the wind blows the last studio prop across the sands.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Karen Weise
title: How Tony Hsieh Tried to Single-Handedly Transform Downtown Las Vegas
description: Mr. Hsieh, who died at 46, tried to revitalize a corner of the city by attracting other entrepreneurs.
content: It was his own personal sandbox, a real-life Sim City that he spent $350 million to build in a neglected corner of Las Vegas, just north of the flash and crowds of the Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Dear Joe’: Advice for Biden
description: What is the greatest challenge facing President-elect Joe Biden? We asked readers that question, and what advice they would give him.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 28, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 28, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about President Trump’s exchange with reporters in the White House on Thursday misstated the last time a Democrat won Georgia in a presidential election. It was 1992, not 1996.
source.name: The New York Times
